title: Great for API debugging but can be a resource hog
body: Postman is my go-to tool for debugging APIs and running automated tests in CI pipelines. The interface is intuitive, and setting up test suites is straightforward. However, it can consume a lot of memory, especially when handling large collections or multiple workspaces. Collaboration features are solid but occasionally lag. Overall, it speeds up development and debugging, though I wish it was a bit lighter on system resources.

title: Essential tool for API debugging and testing
body: Insomnia has become my go-to for debugging REST and GraphQL APIs. Its intuitive interface allows me to quickly set up requests and inspect responses, which speeds up troubleshooting. I especially appreciate the environment variable features, enabling seamless switching between dev, staging, and production endpoints. The ability to export requests makes sharing test cases with the team straightforward. Overall, it integrates well into my workflow and has saved countless hours compared to manual cURL commands.

title: Great for API testing but UI can get cluttered
body: As a junior backend engineer, I use Postman mostly for debugging APIs and running quick manual tests before automated ones kick in. It’s super handy to set up different environments and switch between them easily. The interface is mostly intuitive, though it can feel cluttered when you have lots of collections open. Also, syncing across devices occasionally lags, which can be a bit frustrating. Overall, it’s a solid tool that speeds up my workflow, but there’s room for improvement in the UI and performance.

title: Efficient API testing with minor interface quirks
body: As a QA engineer, I rely on Postman primarily for debugging REST APIs and creating automated test suites. Its ability to quickly organize requests and run tests in our CI pipeline has streamlined our workflow significantly. The environment variable management is intuitive, which helps when switching between dev and staging servers. However, the interface can sometimes feel cluttered, especially when managing large collections, and the desktop app occasionally lags on larger projects. Despite these minor issues, Postman remains a solid tool that balances powerful features with usability.

title: Good for quick API checks but lacks advanced features
body: As a QA Engineer, I often use Hoppscotch for debugging APIs during development. It offers a clean interface for sending requests and inspecting responses, which is helpful for quick manual checks. However, I found it lacking in automation capabilities, such as integrating with CI pipelines or running test suites, which are essential for comprehensive QA workflows. Additionally, the lack of detailed logging and environment management makes it harder to maintain complex testing scenarios. Overall, it's useful for simple tasks but falls short for more advanced API testing needs.

title: Good for quick API checks but could be smoother
body: I've been using Insomnia mainly to debug APIs during backend development. It’s pretty straightforward to set up requests and inspect responses, which helps when I'm testing endpoints locally. However, I found the UI a bit clunky and sometimes slow to load larger collections. Also, the lack of some advanced features like automated testing within the app means I still have to rely on other tools for CI workflows. Overall, it’s decent for quick checks but not my go-to for more complex tasks.

title: Decent for API testing but lacking in automation
body: I've been using Insomnia primarily for debugging REST APIs, and while it handles manual requests well, the lack of robust automation features is a downside. I need better support for integrating tests into our CI pipeline, which Insomnia doesn’t offer natively. The interface is clean and straightforward, but it can feel a bit slow with larger projects. Overall, it's fine for quick checks, but I wouldn't rely on it alone for comprehensive API testing workflows.

title: Good for quick tests but lacks depth
body: I use Hoppscotch mainly for debugging APIs during development. While the interface is straightforward for sending requests, it falls short on features like advanced authentication handling and detailed response analysis. There's no easy way to save and organize collections effectively, which slows down workflows when working across multiple projects. For quick one-off tests, it's fine, but for anything beyond that, I find myself switching back to Postman or Insomnia. The tool feels unfinished and not suited for serious backend work.

title: Essential tool for API debugging and testing
body: As a QA engineer, I rely heavily on Insomnia for debugging APIs during integration testing. Its intuitive interface allows me to quickly build and send complex HTTP requests, saving time when isolating issues. I particularly appreciate the ability to organize requests into collections, which streamlines regression testing workflows. The support for environment variables makes switching between staging and production seamless. Additionally, the response viewer provides clear insights into headers and payloads, which is invaluable when diagnosing problems. Overall, Insomnia is a stable, efficient tool that enhances my daily testing processes.

title: Decent tool for API debugging but has limitations
body: I use Insomnia mainly for debugging REST APIs during backend development. The interface is straightforward, and setting up requests with various authentication methods is simple. However, I ran into performance issues when working with larger GraphQL schemas, and the lack of advanced environment management makes it harder to integrate into complex workflows. Also, the UI can sometimes feel sluggish. Overall, it gets the job done for basic API testing, but for more demanding use cases, I’ve found it falls short compared to alternatives.
